p: Some women noted that gender was an issue in holding leadership positions. For example, one respondent noted: “It seemed very difficult for some of the men in my chapter to accept that a woman was leading them. Women were rarely given the word; our suggestions were almost never taken up.” Others noted their multiple intersecting challenges: “in my case, I think it was the factor of: gender + age + command of English” and “being a woman and not particularly tall or loud, I found myself struggling to get attention from ‘senior’ scientists at meetings.” An intersectional lens highlights how individuals often experience discrimination based on social signifiers such as gender, race, class, and sexuality at the same time. These are not discrete categories but intersect; thus, a scientist who is a woman of color and small stature and from a developing country may face multiple levels of discrimination ( 30, 63).
